papers.abstract: As algorithmic models increasingly assist, judge, and manage human life, a growing amount of scrutiny, criticism, and backlash has ensued, calling into question the violence of such powerful applications and demanding a renewed focus on bias, ethics, and governance. At the same time, elite academic institutions and massive tech firms have been adaptively adept at the capture and depoliticizing of its critics [Whittaker 2021]. Calls for a fundamental reckoning with the logics and violences of computation have been largely disciplined into niche new industries of expertise which Phan, Goldenfein, Mann, and Kuch refer to as 'economies of virtue.' In response, this essay explores Black Computational Thought as a critical intervention into the residues of Post-Enlightenment thought mapped onto and subtending contemporary computational logics. By placing computation within such genealogical bounds, we are free to ask the question, what other proximal places might we look to to recover computational practices that challenge colonial logics of coercion? What other genres lay in wait? Black Computational Thought holds open these proximal possibilities and directs our attention to the quotidian, social, opaque, woven, and fugitive practices of computation born from Black diasporic movement.

At the same time, elite academic institutions and massive tech firms have been adaptively adept at the capture and depoliticizing of its critics [Whittaker 2021]. Calls for a fundamental reckoning with the logics and violences of computation have been largely disciplined into niche new industries of expertise which Phan, Goldenfein, Mann, and Kuch refer to as 'economies of virtue.'

Primary Object: critique or criticism against algorithmic models

Context: growing integration of AI/ML technologies into human life across various sectors
Purpose: reconcile conflict between technological advancement and moral issues
Results: establishment of new areas of study focusing on ethical computation practices
Analysis: discussions about reconciling methodological choices with perceived moral failures
Challenge: balancing innovation needs with ethical considerations
Ethical: tension between technical development and moral responsibility
Implications: ongoing dialogue required for navigating complexities
Contradictions: contradiction between rapid tech evolution and slow regulatory processes

papers.abstract: To immerse and engage her learners in the particularly difficult topic of WWII Paris, a French instructor, with assistance from the university libraries and digital humanities lab, embarked upon distinct yet iterative digital projects that allowed students to connect with course material through critical making. Starting with digital mapping and moving to 360° virtual reality video projects, instructor, librarians, and students stitched together fragments of the past to further their collective experience of this historical period via immersive technology. Students’ work was founded upon feminist maker pedagogy and an ethic of care that allowed them to step into others’ perspectives and preserve a cultural memory that future students will build upon.

events.Text: To immerse and engage her learners in the particularly difficult topic of WWII Paris, a French instructor, with assistance from the university libraries and digital humanities lab, embarked upon distinct yet iterative digital projects that allowed students to connect with course material through critical making.

Secondary Object: that allowed students to connect with course material through critical making.

Context: to immerse and engage her learners in the particularly difficult topic of WWII Paris
Purpose: seek to make complex historical subjects accessible and immersive for learners
Method: utilized various digital tools and platforms supported by academic resources including access to libraries’ collections and digital humanities methodologies.
Results: increased student involvement and interaction with the course material
Analysis: focus shifted towards active learning strategies over traditional teaching methods
Challenge: faced challenges like time management resource availability and balancing institutional demands.
Ethical: promotes inclusivity and accessibility especially for students facing disparities.
Implications: expanding similar initiatives to other educational contexts offers promising avenues.

events.Text: Starting with digital mapping and moving to 360° virtual reality video projects, instructor, librarians, and students stitched together fragments of the past to further their collective experience of this historical period via immersive technology.

Context: starting with digital mapping and moving to 360° virtual reality video projects
Purpose: enhancing participants' collective experience of this historical period via immersive technology
Method: collaborative efforts between educators and students utilizing advanced technologies
Results: creation of immersive content including fragments and positive impact on engagement
Challenge: complexities inherent in coordinating diverse teams and ensuring technical compatibility
Ethical: ethical concerns arise regarding accessibility equity and data privacy
Implications: potential to influence educational practices and open doors for future studies
